preface.title: Release Notes
preface.para:
These release notes cover features and changes for:
SciDB Community Edition (CE)
SciDB Enterprise Edition (EE)
Paradigm4 Labs (P4Labs), which is a collection of external tools (such as SciDB-R) maintained in the form of GitHub repositories.

Note that we may deprecate operators but commit to providing advance notice about operators that will be removed in the next release. Operators marked for deprecation below are present in R&scidb_version; but will be removed in R13.12.

section.title: Supported Operating Systems
section.para: SciDB 13.9 supports three platforms: Ubuntu 12.04, RHEL 6, and CentOS 6.

section.title: Community Edition Features and Changes
section.para:
This version includes the following features and changes:
Significant performance improvements in redimension and redimension_store, mainly in memory and disk space consumption.
A new aggregate operator, cumulate, that computes cumulative aggregates, along a user- specified dimension, using user-specified aggregate functions.
If you are upgrading from a previous version of SciDB, refer to the Upgrade section of the User Guide. Note that there is a new, required parameter, enable-catalog-upgrade, that you must set.
The special value, NA, is deprecated. You can use NaN or Null instead.
The multiply operator is deprecated, and will be removed in the next version of SciDB.
To multiply dense matrices, use the gemm operator.
To multiply sparse matrices, use the spgemm operator, which is available in the Enterprise Edition.

section.title: Enterprise Edition Features and Changes
section.para: This version includes the following features and changes:

listitem.para: A new math operator spgemm for sparse matrix multiply.

The timestamp data type supports a coercion from the SciDB string type whose argument is a string representation of a 'date time' pair—the exact form of the date and time component strings are specified by the POSIX standard. Previous versions of this function would have silently accepted an argument of the form 'YYYY-MM-DD', even though the time component of the time stamp is absent; in 13.9 the coercion now rejects this argument and throws an error.
The names first and last were used both as functions and as aggregates. For clarity, we renamed the aggregate versions to first_value and last_value.

The following operators are deprecated, and will be removed in the next version of SciDB:
cumsum and cumprod: use the new cumulate operator
linregr and logistregr: use the glm operator
solve: use the gesvd operator

section.title: Paradigm4 Labs Features and Changes
section.para: We make available a collection of external tools in the form of GitHub repositories at http://github.com/paradigm4.

P4 Labs features:
A new online tool called configurator that provides assistance selecting and building the initialization parameters file, config.ini. See https://github.com/paradigm4/configurator.
A beta-version cluster deployment script that significantly simplifies the installation of SciDB to a cluster. See https://github.com/paradigm4/deployment. Make sure to check the README file there to be aware of the security issues. Use at your own risk.

listitem.para: The dimensions operator sometimes reports incorrect start, length, low and high values for unbounded arrays. Correct values may be obtained using apply to translate a dimension into an attribute, followed by a min / max aggregate.
The difference between the largest and the smallest dimension value in an array must not exceed (2^61 - 1).
The adddim and deldim operators may return incorrect results, or cause a system crash, when used in certain queries.

The repart operator sometimes performs slower than it needs to. This applies to the automatically-inserted repart commands as well. Consider using a combination of apply and redimension as an alternative to repart.
Non-integer dimensions will be rearchitected in the next release. For details on the current prototype, please see http://www.scidb.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=1172.
For operators gemm and gesvd, the chunks of the input must be square, and must have a chunk interval from 32 to 1024.

The redimension operator is more restrictive than it needs to be—it does not allow nullable attributes to be turned into dimensions and it unnecessarily requires input and output dimensions to match chunk sizes. Use the substitute operator to remove null values from the data.
Use the apply operator to rename input dimensions, so that redimension can accept them.

Whenever a query requires filtering on dimension values, the filter operator performs slower than it needs to. In the vast majority of cases, between, subarray, cross_join, or a combination of them, will substantially increase performance. For more information about using cross_join as a dimensions filter, see the slides at http://www.scidb.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=1204.
Using mixed-case names for databases is not recommended. Use all lowercase names to avoid problems.
